nutrient_management.question: Which of the following is not an essential nutrient for plants?
Which of the following plant nutrients is a cation in soils?
Which of the following plant nutrients is a macronutrient?
Which of the following regulates stomatal openings in plants?
Which of the following is a beneficial element that is important in animal nutrition?
Which of the following plant nutrient forms is most immobile in soil?
Which of the following is an uptake form of nitrogen?
Which of the following is an uptake form of phosphorus?
Which of the following is a chemical uptake form of potassium?
Which of the following nutrients is a micronutrient?
At which of the following plant growth stages would you expect the highest demand for soil nutrients?
Chelates are commonly used to increase the availability of
Which of the following is the least available source of nutrients?
If a nutrient is released to the soil during decomposition of an organic material, ______ has occurred.
When a plant nutrient is absorbed with water that is moving to and into the plant root, the nutrient uptake process is called ______.
A major way calcium is supplied to plants is by ______.
Which of the following is more soluble in a flooded soil than in an upland soil?
Which of the following soil textures would likely have the lowest soil fertility?
In which of the following cases would you expect the greatest nitrogen mineralization?
Which of the following is not needed for rapid nitrification to occur?
Conditions which favor volatile losses of nitrogen as ammonia include ______.
Denitrification is the conversion of ______ to gaseous forms like dinitrogen and oxides of nitrogen.
Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is the process where atmospheric nitrogen is converted to ammonia in the root nodules of ______.
Immobilization of inorganic N during decomposition will be most likely if the material decomposing has a C:N ratio of ______.
A condition which favors symbiotic nitrogen fixation is ______.
Cropping systems that substantially increase or decrease soil pH from pH 6.5 can ______ P availability.
Soil sampling in a non-uniform field should be by the ______ method.
The depth of sampling no-till soils as compared to conventionally tilled soils is ______.
Nutrient concentrations ______ change with depth.
At which of the following soil test levels would you expect the greatest crop response?
How are soil surveys useful in a soil sampling plan? They ______.
Which of the following concepts of fertilizer recommendations increases soil fertility level most slowly?
If a soil contains 40 lb P/acre, it contains ______ ppm P
Fertilizer recommendations obtained from a plant tissue analysis are ______ used to make a foliar fertilizer recommendation during that crop year.
______ plant parts should be sampled to obtain reliable tissue test results.
Which is the best sample pretreatment for a tissue sample prior to submitting the sample?

answer_options.a: keep warm in an air-tight plastic bag
answer_options.b: partially air dry in a paper bag
answer_options.c: keep cool in a sealed plastic bag
answer_options.d: keep cool in a paper bag

nutrient_management.question: ______ is the plant nutrient concentration below which crop growth rate declines significantly.
The chlorophyll meter determines ______ sufficiency in a crop.
Which of the following would not usually be a good source of N?
The rate of N release is least affected by microbial activity for ______.
If substantial ammonia is lost after application of UAN, a ______ inhibitor might reduce this loss.
Which of the following nitrogen fertilizer sources has the least % nitrogen?
Which of the following P sources is a liquid?
What is the most common form of potassium fertilizer?
If a fertilizer is 13-13-13 on an oxide basis, what is the analysis on an elemental basis?
The portion of a fertilizer that easily dissolves in water is ______.
How many lbs of 10-20-10 should be applied to an acre if the fertilizer recommendation is 60 lbs of P₂O₅?
How many lbs of 10-20-10 should be applied to an acre if the fertilizer recommendation is 26 lbs of P?
If a manure contains 1.9% P on a dry basis and is 60% solids, what is the 'as is' (wet basis) P concentration?
Which of the following is the best way to maximize plant available N in manure?
When sampling a manure pile for analysis, how many samples is enough?
Potassium can be leached into subsoil if long-term additions of ______ are applied to a soil.
Split applications of nitrogen fertilizer ______ as compared to a single application of the same amount of nitrogen.
______ application of P usually results in the most available P.
Which of the following nutrient placement methods is common for small grains and forages?
Which of the following times of nutrient application is likely to use the least tractor time?
Which of the following factors creates a situation where seed germination is likely reduced?

answer_options.a: place a fertilizer with a high salt index near the seed
answer_options.b: place a fertilizer with low solubility near a seed
answer_options.c: place a fertilizer with a low ammonia content near a seed

nutrient_management.question: As soil pH decreases, ______ increases.
Which of the following is the best measure of total acidity in a soil?
Which of the following fertilizers has the greatest potential to decrease soil pH?
Which of the following soils would have the highest lime requirement to meet a target pH of 6.5?
At which of the following soil pHs would phosphorus be most available for plant uptake?
Which of the following micronutrients is more available at pH 7 than at pH 5?
Which of the following actually neutralizes soil acidity when lime is applied?
Which of the following is not used in determining a lime recommendation?
Lime passing through which of the following mesh sizes would be of greatest benefit in neutralizing soil acidity?
ECCE is the product of Effectiveness and ______.
If the ECCE of a liming material is 65 and the lime recommendation for a state is based on a material with an ECCE of 80, how should lime rate be adjusted for the material with an ECCE of 65?
Which of the following is least likely to change soil pH?
Which of the following is characteristic of a N deficiency?

answer_options.a: leaves yellow at the bottom of the plant first
answer_options.b: leaves yellow at the top of the plant first
answer_options.d: interveinal chlorosis inward from leaf margins

nutrient_management.question: Soil testing and plant tissue tests are usually ______.

answer_options.b: done monthly during the growing season
answer_options.c: used to test for nutrient deficiencies

nutrient_management.question: Which of the following best describes adaptive nutrient management?

answer_options.a: adjust nutrient applications to optimize yields and profits
answer_options.b: adjust nutrient applications for highest yields
answer_options.c: adjust nutrient management for acceptable yields and profits

nutrient_management.question: Production history or level of management is a good way to determine ______.
Which of the following is not part of the 4R system?
Which of the following is commonly used to P loss assessments at the field scale?
Which of the following N losses is probably most important for a field of soybeans?
Which of the following conditions allow N-based manure applications?
If a manure contains 0.2% total P and 50% of the P contributes to soil test P, how much would soil test P increase if 5 ton/acre of the manure is applied to a soil?
Sinkholes in a Karst topography area can serve as conduits for N and P movement to ______.
Which of the following is not part of the purpose of a nutrient management plan?
A comprehensive nutrient management plan (CNMP) should discuss ______.
Nutrient budgets consider ______.
The final step in a nutrient management plan is ______.
Which of the following loss pathways is of most concern for loss of nitrate N?
Which of the following loss pathways is of most concern for loss of phosphate from a recently tilled soil?

soil_and_water.question: Which of the following is negatively charged?
Cations are held on the CEC by ________ charges on clay and organic matter.
Which of the following clays contributes most to CEC if the same amount of each clay is present?
Potassium fixation occurs when which of the following clays is present in soil?
If a soil has an EC of 0.6 siemens per meter and contains 20 percent sodium on the CEC, it is a ________ soil.
What is the textural class of soil that is 10 percent clay and 35 percent sand?
Which of the following increases as a soil's clay content increases?
Which of the soil textures listed below has the highest porosity and lowest bulk density?
The maximum value for plant available water is ________.

answer_options.a: greatest in soils with large pores
answer_options.b: smallest in soils with small pores
answer_options.c: the difference between field capacity and wilting point

soil_and_water.question: Which of the following textural classes has the largest potential available water?
Which kind of soil structure would be typical for a good seed bed?
Soil structure modifies the physical properties of soil ________.
Good structure in the subsoil improves ________.
Soil microorganisms cause ________ in soil structure when crop residues are added to soil.
The bulk density of 100 cm3 of dry soil that weighs 145 g is ________ g/cm3.
Which of the following soil textures has the greatest % porosity?
Which of the following can decrease bulk density?
In a typical row crop production system, most of the soil organic matter originates from ________.
The stable form of soil organic matter is called ________.
When organic materials decompose, most of the C ends up as ________.
Which of the following is not an example of a contribution of soil organic matter to soil properties?
Soil organic matter is a source of ________ for crops.
In order to increase soil organic matter levels, ________ must be markedly reduced or eliminated.
Which of the following is most important in carbon sequestration?
Which of the following favors increased soil microbial activity?

answer_options.c: increase in soil water content from 20 to 40 percent of water holding capacity
answer_options.d: decrease in soil water content from 30 to 10 percent of water holding capacity

soil_and_water.question: Which of the following organic materials would be expected to mineralize the most nitrogen?
What is the most important soil property that affects soil health?
A horizon that contains illuviated clay is the ________ horizon.
How many acres in the S1/2, of the S1/2 of Section 29?
The area of a rectangular field that is 1250 feet long and 700 feet wide is ________ acres.
If a field has an 11 foot change in elevation over a distance of 1000 feet, the slope is ________%.
Poorly drained soils that are wet most of the year are often ________.
Which of the following irrigation systems is least labor intensive?
Which of the below is an example of sub-surface drainage?
If a septic system is being planned for a housing subdivision, a ________ order soil survey is needed.
Knowing the drainage class of soil is helpful when building a ________.
Which kind of erosion removes a thin layer of soil?
Which of the following is a kind of wind erosion that forms dust storms?
Any factor that ________ runoff and ________ surface protection, increases erosion.
Which of the following factors does not affect wind erosion?
The amount of soil that can be lost by erosion, while crop production is maintained economically for the long-term is ________.
In most situations, surface soil ________ will be lower after water erosion occurs.
Which of the following would be an acceptable conservation practice for a steep slope?
Maintaining surface residues on a soil will ________ surface soil warming in the Spring.
Soil erosion potential is highest in which of the following?
What is the percent crop residue cover if the average number of residue intersections is 20 at 6 inch increments over 50 feet?
When crop residues are removed from a field, soil ________ increases.
Subsurface compaction from tillage usually starts ________.

answer_options.c: well below the depth of tillage

soil_and_water.question: Seedling emergence is hindered by ________.
Maintaining crop residues on the surface and ________ reduce surface compaction.
________ decreases odor and NH3 losses from biosolids.
Which of the following increases soil water storage?
Which of the following has the greatest impact on infiltration?
Runoff decreases as ________ increases.
Leaching is most impacted by ________.
Rapid water movement downward in large pores after a rain is called ________.
Soil ________ has little effect on sulfate movement.
A day when there is ________ probability of precipitation would be best for pesticide application to minimize pesticide losses in runoff.
Phosphorus is transported by ________ from fields.
Phosphorus transport from a field can be reduced by ________.
Water moving horizontally in a soil is called ________ flow.
Maximum plant available water is ________ minus ________.
Maximum ET generally occurs ________.
Which of the following must exist for ET to occur?
Excessive soil moisture generally ________ nutrient uptake.
Limited soil moisture generally ________ nutrient uptake.
The irrigation method where water is applied at low volume is ________.
________ are raised soil areas used to improve drainage.

Irrigation is needed when the soil moisture deficit equals 6 inches. How long will it be before irrigation is needed if the average daily ET is 0.5 inches and one 1 inch rainfall event occurs with no runoff? Initial soil moisture deficit is 2 inches.
Tile drain spacing is smallest for a ________ soil.
________ irrigation allows the most control to prevent runoff.
Which of the following pollutants is in water is not generally attributed to agriculture?
What standards are used to determine if a water body is impaired?
Nutrient enrichment of a surface water is termed ________.
Ten ppm of NO3 - (mw is 62) is ________.
Which of the following NO3 - concentrations would be considered hazardous to an infant?
Well water contamination from surface water can be prevented by using a ________.
Sediments in runoff decrease ________ in surface waters.
A ________ is specifically designed to improve ground water quality before ground water can move to a stream.
Which of the following are most sensitive to saline water?

pest_management.question: A pest is an organism that _______ another organism.
IPM has a main goal of _______ pesticide use.
A quarantine is an example of which pest management strategy?
When using proper pest monitoring procedures ________.

answer_options.b: treatments are usually scheduled based on time intervals and not pest levels
answer_options.c: need for treatment does not consider economics
answer_options.d: treatments are based on pest levels and economics

pest_management.question: In developing a sampling scheme for a pest, _________ does NOT need to be considered.
Which of the following causes a disease to occur in a pest reducing the pest population?
________ is an important way pests are transported to host plants.
Which of the following is NOT one of the three sides of the disease development triangle?
Which of the following pathogens usually survives only in living tissue?
When a pest invades the plant between plant cells, it is called _______.
________ is a major way insects feed.
Insect damage to a crop can occur when ________ coincides with crop growth.
Insects that have egg, larva, pupa, and adult stages undergo _______ metamorphosis.
Which of the following helps weeds survive and be competitive?
Which of the following is often the most important limiting factor for a weed competing with a crop when the crop out grows the weed?
Which of the following diagnostic tools fails to show the variability in pest characteristics?
Which is the most insect specific method of sampling for insects?
If insects are clumped in specific parts of the field, ________ samples should be taken.
Soil for a nematode analysis should be _________ before shipping.
Which of the following can be used to predict future pest populations?
Which of the following is LEAST helpful in identifying a pest?
Mites have _______ legs.
Which of the following pests is pictured below?
Which of the following characteristics is used to identify broadleaf weed seedlings?
Which of the following characteristics are used to identify grass weed seedlings?
Which of the following is NOT a common example of non-pest damage to crops?
In integrated pest management, the economic injury level is the level where ________ equal the _______ due to damage by the pest.

answer_options.a: pest management costs, loss in income

pest_management.question: The action threshold (AT) is the level of pest injury when pest control will prevent the ______ from being reached.
Natural enemies of pests _______ pest populations.
Cropping history of a field can be used to identify pest ________.

An insecticide costs $10 per acre. The current value of the crop is $2.50/bu, the lost crop yield of each insect invasion is 10% of yield, and the yield before the insect invasion was 100 bu/acre. How much will per acre income increase with one treatment of the insecticide as compared to no treatment?
If a pest can exclude or overcome a disease it is considered ______.
A limitation of GM crops is ______.

answer_options.c: lack of tolerance to wet soils
answer_options.d: lack of marketability in some countries

pest_management.question: __________ are used to maintain natural enemies of insect pests.
Which of the following factors allow a pest to overcome host plant resistance?
Which of the following is important in many disease management programs?
Which of the following is LEAST LIKELY to be used to control a pest?
The time during the season when a crop should be kept free of weeds is the ________ period.
Which of the following biological control agents is pictured below?
Biological control agents that work best are ________.

answer_options.d: not indigenous to the crop or area

pest_management.question: Crop sensitivity to a pesticide can vary with ________.
Which of the following does NOT encourage pesticide resistance to develop?

answer_options.a: alternating pesticides with different modes of action
answer_options.b: repeated use of a single pesticide
answer_options.c: repeated use of pesticides with the same mode of action
answer_options.d: repeated use of high pesticide rates

pest_management.question: ________ pesticides exert their pesticidal action where they are placed on a plant.
Which of the following increases the possibility of genetic resistance developing in a pest?
Which of the following increases the potential for non-target crop injury?

Which of the following water quality parameters can impact herbicide efficacy?
If a non-target crop has an albino appearance, it may have been sprayed with a ________.
_________ is important when applying herbicides to herbicide resistant crops.
Which of the following insecticides are most persistent in soils?
Which of the following insecticides target insect eggs?
________ fungicides are absorbed by the plant and distributed internally to prevent disease infection or kill the pathogen without harming the plant.
________ fungicides are designed to kill specific pests.
Which of the following pesticide characteristics would be expected to lead to the most groundwater pollution?
Which of the following site characteristics increases the potential for soil and water pollution by a pesticide?
If a pesticide is moderately toxic, the label will have the signal word ________.
Worker Protection Standards do not specifically require ________.
________ must provide assistance to workers who have been poisoned by a pesticide under Worker Protection Standards.
Ten (10) ppm is equivalent to ________.
Acute pesticide poisoning is how poisonous a pesticide is to humans after ______ exposure(s).
Pesticides should NOT be stored in a ________ building.
Which would you do first if a pesticide spill occurs?

crop_management.question: Which of the following is normally not considered when comparing a crop rotation with a monoculture system?
Which of the following is an advantage of a crop rotation over a monoculture system?

answer_options.b: timing fertilizer and pesticide application easier
answer_options.d: risk spread across more than one commodity

crop_management.question: Which of following is a limitation of a crop rotation over a monoculture system?

answer_options.c: yield of all crops in the rotation increase

crop_management.question: ________ increases available N, reduces erosion and increase infiltration.
A double cropping system is where two crops are grown in the same field over ________.
________ is not a limitation of cover or companion crops.
Fields are fallowed to conserve ________.
Pesticide carryover is most important in ________ crops.
________ is when a plant produces a chemical toxin that impairs the growth of a different plant.
In clean-till systems, tillage can spread ________.
Starter fertilizer is commonly recommended for ________.
The soil test values in the top 2 inches of soil are ________ soil test values below 2 inches in a no-till situation.
Which of the following must be sufficiently high to justify conversion of non-cropland to cropland?
Offspring of two plants which differ genetically are ________.
Pollination is ________ in an open-pollinated variety.
Which of the following is usually most important when selecting a variety for planting?
Transgenic crops contain ________.

answer_options.b: altered genes from the same species

crop_management.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a well-designed field trial?

answer_options.d: irrigation of a typically dryland crop

crop_management.question: GMOs include ________.
If the yields of varieties A, B and C are 45, 50, and 44 bu per acre, respectively, and the LSD is 5, which of the following is true?

answer_options.a: there are no significant differences in yield
answer_options.b: the yield of variety B is significantly higher than variety C
answer_options.c: the yield of variety B is significantly higher than varieties A and C
answer_options.d: the yield of variety A is significantly higher than variety C

crop_management.question: Which of the following is not usually found on a seed information tag?
Seed quality is usually highest for seed stored under ________.
Which of the following is a limitation of seed treatment?
Storage in a ________ likely decreases bacterial inoculum viability the most.
Which germination test is best to evaluate germination under optimum conditions?
If pure seed content is 90% and germination is 90%, what is the % PLS?
If % pure live seed is 80% and the recommended seeding rate is 80 lbs per acre, what adjusted seeding rate should be used?
A benefit of using certified seed is ________.
Which of the following would most likely decrease germination percentage?
Which of the following factors is not used in determining depth of planting?
Which of the following factors is usually most important in determining when to plant?
Which of the following is most likely the result of seeding a summer crop too early?
Which of the following would potentially lead to a reduced seeding rate?
If you count 10 plants in 5 sq ft of a field at several points in that field, what is the approximate plant population?
Seeding rate is ________ plant population.
Advantages of starter fertilizer include ________.
The crop growth stage where roots, stems and leaves develop is ________.
Growing degree days are not useful in determining when to ________.
If the base temperature is 60°F, the daily temperature is 80°F and the maximum temperature is 95°F, how many heat units have accumulated?
In many crops, night length is important in triggering ________.
The growing point of a grass is ________.
The optimum temperature for crop growth and development ________ with crop growth stage.
Water needs of a crop typically increase during the season to a maximum, followed by ________.
Which of the following accelerates canopy closure?
A plant that lives 10 years is a ________.
Crop root growth can be affected by ________.
Which root system concentrates nutrient uptake in surface soil?
A crop should be replanted when stand is lost due to some stress, when ________.

answer_options.d: when you have no crop insurance

crop_management.question: Which of the following may eliminate the possibility of replanting?
When diagnosing a crop production problem in the field, you should ________.

answer_options.c: compare damaged areas with normal areas

crop_management.question: Which of the following is probably not helpful in diagnosing a crop problem in the field?
Which of the following data are most precise?
________ is used to locate a position in a field.
________ is used to apply fertilizers, pesticides and seeds at different rates across a field.
________ is an area that is managed similarly for a given crop input.
Sandy soils have greater ________ than clay loam soils which can affect yield.
Geographical coordinates combine ________ and ________.
Yield maps ________ from year to year for the same crop.
Yield monitors are ________.

answer_options.b: used to estimate crop yields prior to harvest
answer_options.d: used to estimate yield variation within a field

crop_management.question: Harvest date is affected by ________.
Which of the following harvest conditions most likely would reduce seed quality?
Identity-preserved (IP) crops are ________.

answer_options.a: used in strip cropping with cross-pollinated varieties of the same crop
answer_options.b: stored in the same bin as other varieties of the same crop
answer_options.d: kept separate from other varieties of the same crop

crop_management.question: Which of the following factors is most important in maintaining crop quality during storage?
Which of the following most likely will damage grain kernels?
Crop mix on a farm is used to reduce ________.
If the value of a crop is $3/bu and a production practice costs $11.50/acre, which of the following yield increases would make the production practice profitable?
________ is a commodity crop.
If the current local cash price of a crop is $12/bushel and the future price a specific date is $9/bushel, the basis is ________.

V1_benchmark_questions.question: Alfalfa has the potencial to yeild up to ____ tons/acre on good soil.
Applying herbicides directly to cotton is harmful to the cotton because it is
The are ____ in a section.
At what growth stage does the embryo develop into new plant?

At what growth stage is corn most vulnerable to hot temperatures and dry soils?
Carbon Dioxide+water Chlorophyll and light energy ____+ oxygen
Forage legumes ________ digestible protein compared to grasses?
For each 1% of organic matter in the soil, ____ pounds of nitrogen per acre may be available for wheat or small grain use.
High water-holding capacity
How many growing degree days are there if the maximum temperature was 85 and the minimum was 55?
How often should soil tests be taken to aid in maintaining a good forage stand?

answer_options.d: soil tests are not needed for forage production

V1_benchmark_questions.question: If a seed tag stated percent germination at 80% and the purity at 80%, what is the pure live-seed ratio?
If a seed tag stated percent germination at 80% and the purity at 90%, what is the pure live-seed ratio?
If a soil test calls for 1200 ENM per acre, how many tons of lime should be applied?

answer_options.d: depends upon the ENM of the lime

V1_benchmark_questions.question: If you are going to double crop soybeans after wheat, which soybean maturity should be used for your area?
If you planted a soybean variety in extreme northern Missouri in May that was suited for extreme southeast Missouri, what would happen?

answer_options.a: It would mature a few weeks later.
answer_options.b: It would mature a few weeks earlier.
answer_options.c: It would stay green until frost.

V1_benchmark_questions.question: If you want to establish legumes in a grass pasture, what would you not want to do?

answer_options.a: Apply large amounts of N fertilizer.
answer_options.d: Control weeds the previous fall prior to the establishment of legumes.

V1_benchmark_questions.question: If you were a plant breeder and wanted to go to the origin of soybeans in order to find resistance of rust, where would you go?
If you were interested in producing a lot of mid-summer annual legume forage but your soils were droughty, which legume would you choose?
In cotton production what are DD-60s?

answer_options.a: GMO cotton that does not produce seed
answer_options.b: a class of insecticides that are specific for cotton
answer_options.c: heat unit measurements used to manage and monitor cotton
answer_options.d: a grading system for cotton lint

V1_benchmark_questions.question: In southeast Missouri you are more likely to find which growth habitat of soybeans?

Low water-holding capacity
Mixture of pore spaces

answer_options.b: observing plants at the perimeter of the field.

V1_benchmark_questions.question: Nutrients absorbed gradually
Nutrients pass through quickly
Other than providing water to meet crop needs, why are rice fields flooded?

answer_options.b: to provide water for mosquito reproduction, which are needed for proper pollination
answer_options.d: to increase the availability of nutrients

V1_benchmark_questions.question: The parent line for registered or certified seed.
The part of a chromosome that determines individual plant characteristics is called a/an

answer_options.a: provide a source of carbohydrates to humans.
answer_options.b: use light energy to provide food.

Requires labeling by law.

seed used to produce foundation seed.
Soybeans begin flowering after night lengths
Sunflower heads move toward the sun. This is an example of
There are ____ sections in a township?

answer_options.b: Using glyphosate every year on the same field

V1_benchmark_questions.question: This is the source of food for the new seedling until new leaves develop.
This micronutrient is deficient in very acid soil, sandy soils and is important for nitrogen fixation in soybeans.
Under what conditions would you increase soybean seeding rate?

answer_options.a: if lodging has been a problem
answer_options.b: if using high-quality seed with higher than 85% germination
answer_options.c: If planting very early or very late
answer_options.d: if planting under ideal conditions in 30-inch rows

V1_benchmark_questions.question: The Universal Soil Loss Equation, A=RKLSCP, is used to calculate those factors that contribute to soil erosion. What does P stand for in the equation?
Using natural predators of harmful insects to control pests is an example of
What are the three types of conservation tillage?
What crops are examples of monocots?

answer_options.e: all of the choices are correct

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What does K stand for in the fertilizer analysis N-K-P?
What effect will delays in planting dates have on corn yields?

answer_options.a: yields will increase about 2 bushels per acre.
answer_options.b: yields will increase about 10 bushels per acre.
answer_options.c: There is no increase or decrease in yield.
answer_options.d: Yields will be decreased more as the planting date becomes later.

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What is a biennial?

answer_options.a: plants that bloom two times per year
answer_options.b: plants that complete their life cycle in two growing years

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What is a characteristic(s) of soybean cyst nematode infection?

answer_options.b: symptoms occur across the entire field
answer_options.d: both healthy roots and symptoms occur across the field
answer_options.e: both symptoms occur across the field and stunted roots

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What is a hybrid corn?

answer_options.b: the cross between two inbred lines
answer_options.c: the cross between two heterozygous lines
answer_options.d: the cross between corn and grain sorghum

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What is a legume?

answer_options.b: the area of a plant where the leaf meets the stem
answer_options.c: a family of plants whose seeds are formed in fruits called pods
answer_options.d: plants that complete their life cycle over two growing years

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What is/are an advantage(s) of Red Clover over Alfalfa for use as a pasture or hay crop?

answer_options.c: grows better on poorly drained soils
answer_options.d: both more drought resistant and more winter hardy
answer_options.e: both more winter hardy and grows better on poorly drained soils

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What is meant by "integrated pest management"?

answer_options.a: using only chemicals to control pests
answer_options.b: using a combination of chemicals, biological, and physical controls to manage pests
answer_options.c: using only organic methods of controlling pests
answer_options.d: not using any means other than biological to control pests

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What is not a secondary nutrient?

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What is the difference between rotational grazing and management intensive grazing?

answer_options.b: Rotational grazing is for sheep whereas management intensive is for cattle.
answer_options.c: Rotational grazing involves two to seven pastures whereas management intensive involves eight or more pastures.
answer_options.d: Rotational grazing involves grass pastures whereas management intensive grazing involves legume pastures only.

V1_benchmark_questions.question: What three conditions must be present for a disease to develop?

answer_options.a: soil nutrient deficiency, environmental conditions, and susceptible host
answer_options.b: susceptible host, favorable environmental conditions, and virulent pathogen
answer_options.c: virulent pathogen, cold climate, and soil nutrient deficiency
answer_options.d: hot and dry conditions, virulent pathogen, and soil nutrient deficiency

answer_options.d: It will yield better than wheat planted in the fall.

answer_options.b: improves soil structure and organic matter content

V1_benchmark_questions.question: Which of the following statements would be a benefit of leaving crop residue on the planting field?

answer_options.d: increases chance of crop insects and diseases

V1_benchmark_questions.question: Why are weeds considered pests?

answer_options.b: They can produce their own food through photosynthesis.
answer_options.c: They are immune to many crop diseases.

V1_benchmark_questions.question: Why is cotton not produced in the northern climates?

answer_options.a: laws regulating cotton production to south of the Mason-Dixon line
answer_options.b: boll weevils are more prevalent in the northern climates
answer_options.c: diseases that infect cotton overwinter in corn stubble
answer_options.d: cotton requires a long frost-free period

V1_benchmark_questions.question: With everything else being equal, which soil conditions cause the deepest soil compaction?

answer_options.d: soil moisture has no effect on compaction
